fields.description:
*Assessment*

When using 'euca_conf --list-nodes' or 'euca-describe-nodes' to check the status of instances and nodes, the nodes show up in NOTREADY state, even though 'euca-describe-availability-zones' verbose shows the correct information.

{code}
[root@odc-f-13 ~]# euca_conf --list-nodes
NODE	RiseOfAnEmpire		10.105.1.188	NOTREADY
INSTANCE	i-6292df29
INSTANCE	i-ea9d5544

[root@odc-f-13 ~]# euca-describe-nodes
NODE	RiseOfAnEmpire		10.105.1.188	NOTREADY
INSTANCE	i-6292df29
INSTANCE	i-ea9d5544

[root@odc-f-13 ~]# euca-describe-availability-zones verbose
AVAILABILITYZONE	RiseOfAnEmpire	10.104.1.194 arn:euca:eucalyptus:RiseOfAnEmpire:cluster:Moment/
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- vm types	free / max   cpu   ram  disk
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.small	0004 / 0006   1    256     5
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- t1.micro	0004 / 0006   1    256     5
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.medium	0004 / 0006   1    512    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- c1.medium	0002 / 0003   2    512    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.large	0004 / 0006   1   1024    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- c1.xlarge	0002 / 0003   2   2048    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.xlarge	0002 / 0003   2   2048    10
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m1.xlarge	0004 / 0006   1   1024    15
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m3.xlarge	0001 / 0001   4   2048    15
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.2xlarge	0001 / 0001   2   4096    30
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m3.2xlarge	0001 / 0001   4   4096    30
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cc1.4xlarge	0000 / 0000   8   3072    60
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- m2.4xlarge	0000 / 0000   8   4096    60
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- hi1.4xlarge	0000 / 0000   8   6144   120
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cc2.8xlarge	0000 / 0000  16   6144   120
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cg1.4xlarge	0000 / 0000  16   12288   200
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- cr1.8xlarge	0000 / 0000  16   16384   240
AVAILABILITYZONE	|- hs1.8xlarge	0000 / 0000  48   119808  24000

[root@odc-f-13 ~]# euca-describe-instance-types --show-capacity
INSTANCETYPE	Name         CPUs  Memory (MiB)  Disk (GiB)  Used / Total  Used %
INSTANCETYPE	m1.small        1           256           5     2 /     6     33%
INSTANCETYPE	t1.micro        1           256           5     2 /     6     33%
INSTANCETYPE	m1.medium       1           512          10     2 /     6     33%
INSTANCETYPE	c1.medium       2           512          10     1 /     3     33%
INSTANCETYPE	m1.large        1          1024          10     2 /     6     33%
INSTANCETYPE	c1.xlarge       2          2048          10     1 /     3     33%
INSTANCETYPE	m2.xlarge       2          2048          10     1 /     3     33%
INSTANCETYPE	m1.xlarge       1          1024          15     2 /     6     33%
INSTANCETYPE	m3.xlarge       4          2048          15     0 /     1      0%
INSTANCETYPE	m2.2xlarge      2          4096          30     0 /     1      0%
INSTANCETYPE	m3.2xlarge      4          4096          30     0 /     1      0%
INSTANCETYPE	cc1.4xlarge     8          3072          60     0 /     0
INSTANCETYPE	m2.4xlarge      8          4096          60     0 /     0
INSTANCETYPE	hi1.4xlarge     8          6144         120     0 /     0
INSTANCETYPE	cc2.8xlarge    16          6144         120     0 /     0
INSTANCETYPE	cg1.4xlarge    16         12288         200     0 /     0
INSTANCETYPE	cr1.8xlarge    16         16384         240     0 /     0
INSTANCETYPE	hs1.8xlarge    48        119808       24000     0 /     0
{code}
fields.summary: euca_conf --list-nodes/euca-describe-nodes shows Nodes in NOTREADY state

comments.body:
[~hspencer],

Can you provide steps to reproduce so [~mmunn1] can investigate further?

Sorry about that.  Steps for reproduction are as follows:

*Steps*

* Set up Eucalyptus 4.0 cloud with the following topology
** 1 x CLC/UFS/Walrus
** 1 x CC/SC (overlay)
** 1 x NC
** network mode - managed
** CC private interface is the gateway for NCs  (i.e. forwarding and masquerading are set on the CC to be the gateway for the NCs to get to the outside world and to other Eucalyptus components)
* After confirming each component is registered, and resources are being reported back correctly (via 'euca-describe-availability-zones verbose' and 'euca-describe-instance-types --show-capacity'), ran 'euca_conf --list-nodes'

Hope this helps.  Let me know if there are any questions [~mmunn1]/[~viglesias]
Thanks [~hspencer]! Could [~mmunn1] debug live on your system?
My system is at [~mmunn1]'s service.  :-)
[~hspencer] Details for you setup?

[~mmunn1], 

Its in the 'Environment' field above.  I will repost here to make it easier to read:

* euca-describe-services output
{code}
[root@odc-f-13 ~]# euca-describe-services

SERVICE	cluster           	RiseOfAnEmpire	Moment               	ENABLED 	46  	http://10.104.1.194:8774/axis2/services/EucalyptusCC	arn:euca:eucalyptus:RiseOfAnEmpire:cluster:Moment/

[~mmunn1], 

I can try.  I will test it out today, and keep you posted.

[~mmunn1],

Just wondering, if this was from the start, why would it keep the same state if the CC is reporting the NC's resources?
I believe because the IllegalStateException keeps the State from being updated in the clc.

[~tjcramer] I have asked Harold if he can reproduce this.  Restaring the CLC got us out the the NOTREADY and stopping/stating the NC and registering and deregistering the node does not reproduce this.  After the CLC restart everything seems to work as expecting? We were seeing the java.lang.IllegalStateException from the first startup after installing but the CLC restart resolved that. I cannot reproduce this issue.

Hey [~mmunn1],

I have a current cloud right now that shows the same behavior.  

{code}
[root@odc-f-13 ~]# euca_conf --list-nodes

[~hspencer] Is this a new setup? Do you have the steps you used to get in this state?

Here is an error I saw in cloud-error.log on the CLC:

{code}
Sun Jun 1 20:07:35 2014 ERROR [Topology:Eucalyptus.bootstrap:EphemeralConfiguration:arn:euca:bootstrap:Topology::external/.class java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker#2] [com.eucalyptus.component.Topology$TopologyChange.doTopologyChange(Topology.java):1278] START:DISABLED  arn:euca:bootstrap:ViciousLiesAndDangerousRumors:node:10.105.10.7/ NOTREADY->DISABLED=NOTREADY [the node is operating normally

[~hspencer] The lase time you saw this was that after an upgrade as well? Can I take a look at the setup where you see this?
[~lwade] Any particulars on how you got into this state? I have not been able to reproduce this yet.

192.168.7.11 was off the network but had an NC running.  It didn't have credentials synced.  We got it back onto the network and then went through the normal registration steps (after stopping the NC). Then we arrived at the first point in that snippet (one being reported as NOTREADY).

[~lwade] Was the above on 4.0? If it was 4.0 it could take up to 10 minutes for that node to be removed after it is deregistered.
Yup, it was 4.0.
I have not been able to reproduce this isuue.
[~mmunn1], taking up to 10 minutes just to change the output sounds like a bug in itself.  Are you saying this is not reproducible because if you wait that long it works out ok in the end?
[~lwade] No, I am saying I cannot reproduce this issue regardless of the timeout. If you are able to reproduce this at will please list the steps and reopen.
Ok gotcha. I will see if I can spend some time on it. [~jmille], since we saw this on EMEA cloud too, perhaps you can try to replicate as part of your work here?
[~lwade] Taking up to 10 minutes to change the output was an Architectural decision to account for network connection problems. The timeout is hard coded in nodes.java as REFRESH_TIMEOUT.

Reopening the issue.  Having a hardcoded 10 minute timeout isn't sufficient for the customer.  Additionally, this causes triaging issues when understanding the true state of NCs if there is something that causes them to change state relatively quickly (i.e. from ENABLED to DISABLED to ENABLED, etc.)
[~hspencer] I want to make sure we are talking about the same thing here. The customer is seeing the node go to ENABLED state after 10 minutes right?

As I see it there are two separate issues here. One is the 10 minute timeout the other is the node not going to ENABLED even after 10 minutes. Originally I thought that this ticket was for a node the stayed in the NOTREADY state indefinitely and I could not reproduce that issue. The timeout issue is easily fixed although I would need to talk with Chris about whether we really want to do that,  as I believe to timeout was there to make sure the node was really gone an not just a network blip or temporary communication issue. Which issue is the customer actually seeing or having an issue with.

[~decker] Can we change or eliminate the REFRESH_TIMEOUT in Nodes.java to something much smaller? I hesitate to do this because nodes could be lost for short network interruptions, please advise. The problem is that it can take 10 minutes for the node to be removed from the euca-describe-nodes output.

Original issue resolved (nodes staying in NOTREADY state).  Linked ticket EUCA-9744 created which delves into separate issue of a more timely update of the state (rather than the 10 minute refresh today)
Closing in favor of EUCA-9744 which is unresolved.
